Run "New-Alias -Name "ABCD" -Value "foo" -Option "Constant" -Force:$true" first.
then run below command:
try{New-Alias -Name "ABCD" -Value "foo" -Force:$true}catch{write-host "Error:"$_.FullyQualifiedErrorId}

Expect:

> Error:AliasNotWritable,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.NewAliasCommand

Actual:

> New-Alias : Alias is not writeable because alias ABCD is read-only or constant and cannot be written to.
> At line:1 char:5
> - try{New-Alias -Name "ABCD" -Value "foo" -Force:$true}catch{write-host ...
> -     ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
>   - CategoryInfo          : WriteError: (ABCD:String) [New-Alias], SessionStateUnauthorizedAccessException
>   - FullyQualifiedErrorId : AliasNotWritable,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.NewAliasCommand
title: Canot catch exception from New-Alias with existing constant one

body: There are two ways to load a module, Load(Module), or LoadFrom(Path). Load(Module) only seems to look in default (bin) directory, so personal Modules (in $HOME/.powershell/Modules, e.g.) needs LoadFrom() to load it correctly. But it seems that LoadFrom() calls Load() anyway, before attempting to load from path. But since Load() throws an exception if it cannot load, LoadFrom() never gets to try to load from path, resulting in an error. We need to put try..catch around the Load() call, so that if it throws exception, it will still attempt to load from full path. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/powershell/powershell/776)
title: ipmo fails to load personal module

body:
We have a hard-coded resource name, and because `dotnet cli` force a naming pattern for resources, we have this commit f76838c

```
> git show f76838cc019ee9afee46c2b53c610f796cdd1391
```

``` diff
commit f76838c
Author: Sergei Vorobev <sevoroby@microsoft.com>
Date:   Wed Mar 30 18:00:21 2016 -0700

    Fix hardcoded path to resources in EventLogLogProvider.cs

    Conflicts:
        src/System.Management.Automation/logging/eventlog/EventLogLogProvider.cs

diff --git a/src/System.Management.Automation/logging/eventlog/EventLogLogProvider.cs b/src/System.Management.Automation/logging/eventlog/EventLogLo
index eaecb49..378a467 100644
--- a/src/System.Management.Automation/logging/eventlog/EventLogLogProvider.cs
+++ b/src/System.Management.Automation/logging/eventlog/EventLogLogProvider.cs
@@ -41,7 +41,7 @@ namespace System.Management.Automation
             _eventLog = new EventLog();
             _eventLog.Source = source;

-            _resourceManager = new ResourceManager("Logging", System.Reflection.Assembly.GetExecutingAssembly());
+            _resourceManager = new ResourceManager("System.Management.Automation.resources.Logging", System.Reflection.Assembly.GetExecutingAssembl
         }

         internal string SetupEventSource(string shellId)
```

We should address it properly: replace direct ResourceManager usage by generated strongly-typed resources.

body: In light of the PowerShell team switching this week, this PR includes several breaking changes that needed to be done sooner rather than later. **This PR has breaking changes that you absolutely must review.** Please refrain from working within affected projects until this is merged (consider it a code freeze). Unfortunately, due to required rearrangement of submodules and the addition of a subtree, this _cannot_ be rebased, which leaves me with an odd history, and a few commits that could certainly have better messages. You _must_ review this by looking at the actual `git log`, not what GitHub sees, at it includes the commits merged in the subtree import of `libpsl-native` (which need to be included because the history is very important). Summary: - `src/libpsl-native` submodule replaced with subtree import - `src/libpsl-native/test/googletest` submodule added; **must** initialize submodule - Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host renamed to Microsoft.PowerShell.Host - "Modules" manifests added to `mapping.json` and imported correctly - Modules split between `src/Modules`, `src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Host`, and `src/Microsoft.PowerShell.ConsoleHost` in order to merge shared manifests and Core/Full specific manifests - Pester submodules moved to `src/Modules`; **must** reinitialize submodule - .NET CLI **must** be updated to a version which supports `--info` - `runtimes` section added back to `project.json` files; required by latest NuGet in latest CLI - `bootstrap.sh` script added to install all dependencies on Linux; this is due to the `dotnet` feed being deprecated - `PowerShellGitHubDev.psm` refactored - `xunit.sh` deprecated and removed; **must** use `Start-PSxUnit` - `pester.sh` deprecated and removed; **must** use `Start-PSPester` - `build.sh` still deprecated ~~and not updated (TODO)~~; **must** use `Start-PSBuild` - ~~`Add-Type` tests disabled; _must_ get fixed (TODO)~~ - ~~Documentation is _not yet_ updated (TODO)~~ - Resolves #678, #685, #529 /cc @PowerShell/PowerShell --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/powershell/powershell/761)

body:
The "deprecated" PsSnapIn system believes that `System.Management.Automation.dll` depends on `System.Core.dll`, which is false when building for .NET Core. Unfortunately, PowerShell (through the `InitialSessionState` constructor `CreateDefault2()`) still uses the PsSnapIn system to load the SMA assembly, and so throws an internal exception when it can't find `System.Core.dll`.

The PsSnapIn system really needs to be fully removed.

body: Requires PowerShell/psl-monad#44. Due to the difference in assembly layouts between the old and new build systems, some re-architecturing had to be done. This reverts the prior work-around and integrates the necessary fix in a more correct way. ## Remove IsNullOrEmpty requirement of basePaths Not every host must send a list of base paths. The cross-platform host, built with .NET Core's `corehost`, has every dependent assembly in the Trusted Platform Assemblies list, and so does not have any path to give the AssemblyLoadContext. However, due to coupling, the initialization function must still be called so that the type catalog gets initialized. ## Disable PsSnapIn strong name assertion The (sort of deprecated) PsSnapIn system has an assertion that the loaded assemblies' strong names include the processor architecture. However, assemblies built with .NET CLI do not include this in their strong name, so we need to ignore the check. The better solution would be to change the strong name contained in the PsSnapIn, but that's nowhere to be found. The best solution would be to actually deprecate the PsSnapIn system. ## Load via Assembly.Load with fallback to Path This brings back the original code in the AssemblyLoadContext that attempts to load assemblies from their absolute path. We want this in order to not change Core PowerShell's behavior on Windows when built outside of .NET CLI. However, when published as a .NET Core app, all the assemblies are in the Trusted Platform Assemblies list, and so must be loaded via `Assembly.Load` instead of the path. Loading a TPA from an absolute path is designed to fail. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/powershell/powershell/750)
title: Fix the AssemblyLoadContext and Trusted Platform Assemblies problem

body: # Improvement Specifically this enables us to leverage `dotnet-resgen` to auto-generate the `resx` files into `resources` files for the default culture, which are then compiled into the respective assemblies. @vors Since `.resources` no longer need to be compiled on Windows and added to `windows-build`, #732 should be updated to map the `.resx` files into the superproject as well. Requires PowerShell/psl-windows-build#10. # Caveat This requires a change to the C# bindings. The Windows build system takes `file.resx` and compiles `file.resources`, but CLI prepends the assembly name, thus compiling `SMA.file.resources`. So the resource manager in the generated bindings must be adjusted to look for `SMA.file` instead of `file`. Note that C# bindings cannot yet be auto-generated; so if they need to be updated, the above must be changed again. This is still blocked on #395 / dotnet/cli#819. However, the C# bindings need to be updated only if strings are added/removed, not when their content changes. # Localization @vors I've discovered that given localized resources of the form `file.en-US.resx`, `dotnet-resgen` will create a satellite assembly and publish it to `en-US/SMA.resources.dll`, so #666 will not be a technical problem. /cc @SteveL-MSFT @BrucePay @dantraMSFT --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/powershell/powershell/743)
title: Use dotnet-resgen to compile resx files

body:
Introduced in #719 at 78defa739d8729b211844d21c9e18730aa2f0648, since the value for key `System.Console` is now `mscorlib` instead of `System.Console` in `CorePsTypeCatalog.cs`, tab completion of the assembly's types is broken.

``` powershell
$ [System.Console]::<tab>
```

Expect: `TreatControlCAsInput` etc.
Actual: just `WriteLine`

What's more, the types became inaccessible.

Expected:

``` powershell
$ [System.Console]::TreatControlCAsInput
False
```

Actual: nothing, nada, blank.

The `CorePsTypeCatalog.cs` relevant diff:

```
-            typeCatalog["System.Console"] = "System.Console, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b03f5f7f11d50a3a";
+            typeCatalog["System.Console"] = "mscorlib, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=7cec85d7bea7798e";
```

/cc @daxian-dbw @Francisco-Gamino @mirichmo

Time:2016-03-21T19:34:27.4427745Z
At D:\dev\PowerShell\install.ps1:82 char:9

body:
Man allows you to do a Q for quit and then the help goes away and you see the screen as it was before you showed the help.  Our help is in-line and persists after it is done.  We should fit in better by doing what they do.
We should consider doing the same thing for Windows.

labels.description: (LEGACY) Helps filter issues that might be higher priority because they directly affect usability
labels.name: Usability

title: Linux should use less as pager, and respect $PAGER

body:
We alias MAN to be get-help and that is fine BUT it has to work properly.  People need to be able to find their man pages.  

Our behavior is to find the help associated with a name and if we can't, we'll do a search.  I think we need to look for the native help between those two steps.

milestone.title: Future

title: Our MAN (and get-help) should fall through to /usr/bin/man on failure to find something

body:
This is a cultural fit question.
We can take a foo.ps1 script and add #!/usr/local/bin/powershell and do a CHMOD +x and then it can be run from anywhere.  The Q is whether FROM POWERSHELL, a script should be required to have the +X in order to run.  
My undersanding is that all the other shells require this but I'm not sure about other scripting engines - what about Python, node.js etc - do they require +x to run scripts (from their language interpretor)?

labels.description: ideally support can be provided via other mechanisms, but sometimes folks do open an issue to get a

body: This enables building PowerShell through VS Code. The build task launches the installed version of PowerShell and runs `Start-PSBuild`. This enables a `launch` debug task to immediately debug the `powershell` process, without having to attach to an external process. Note that it launches the built version of PowerShell as `powershell -c 'exit'`. This should be modified to suit a user's needs. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/powershell/powershell/699)
